Choose Scab-Resistant Cultivars like - Crimson Crisp,
Crismos Gold, Pristine etc
Solution 2: Shred fallen leaves in autumn/winter. Spray fallen leaves with urea

Solution 1: Prune out dead or diseased branches.
Solution 2: All the infected plant should be burned buried or sent to a munciple composite site.

Solution 1: Applying Preventive sprays of copper-based fungicides
Solution 2: Removing nearby cedar trees

Solution 1: Use of Actigard in Chile Peppers
Solution 2: Use indexed pathogen-negative seed

Solution 1: Fungicides that are active against brown rot and Botrytis
Solution 2: Avoid early irrigation as this may cause premature powdery mildew infections to rise.

Disease: Cercospora Leaf Spot or Gray Leaf Spot
Solution 1: Epidemic’s onset and/or slows the rate of disease development.
Solution 2: Hybrids with partial resistance to GLS are available. Ask your seed supplier for these hybrids.

Solution 1: Use triazole-based fungicides to control common rust on maize.
Solution 2: Plant corn varieties that are resistant to common rust to reduce the risk of infection.

Solution 1: Use fungicides such as strobilurins or triazoles to control northern leaf blight.
Solution 2: Plant hybrids resistant to northern leaf blight to reduce the risk of disease.

Solution 1: Culture, Sanitation
Solution 2: Resistance, Fungicide Sprays

Solution 1: Remove infected wood, and apply fungicides to reduce spread.
Solution 2: Use resistant grapevine varieties and apply preventative fungicides during key growth stages to reduce the risk of Esca infection

Solution 1: Remove and destroy affected leaves to reduce the spread of Isariopsis Leaf Spot
Solution 2: Use fungicides like chlorothalonil or sulfur to control the disease during active growth.

Solution 1: Remove infected trees to limit the spread of Huanglongbing in your orchard
Solution 2: Control the vector (Asian citrus psyllid) with insecticides to prevent the spread of the bacteria.

Solution 1: Apply copper-based fungicides to protect peach trees from bacterial infections.
Solution 2: Remove infected leaves and fruit to reduce bacterial spread.

Solution 1: Use chlorothalonil-based fungicides to control early blight and prevent further spread.
Solution 2: Rotate crops to reduce the buildup of early blight pathogens in the soil.

Solution 1: Use fungicides with metalaxyl to control late blight during wet weather conditions.
Solution 2: Remove and destroy infected potato plants to prevent late blight from spreading.

Solution 1: Use fungicides like neem oil or sulfur to treat and control powdery mildew on squash.
Solution 2: Improve air circulation by spacing plants adequately and pruning leaves to reduce humidity and mildew growth.

Solution 1: Water strawberries properly, avoiding overhead watering, and using drip irrigation to prevent leaf scorch.
Solution 2: Apply mulch around strawberry plants to conserve soil moisture and protect roots from heat stress, reducing leaf scorch.

Solution 1:
Remove symptomatic plants from your garden or greenhouse to prevent the spread of bacteria to healthy 
plants.
Solution 2: Copper-containing bactericides provide partial disease control.

Solution 1: Removal of selected branches from individual plants
Solution 2: Fungicides labeled for use on vegetables and containing copper or chlorothalonil

Solution 1: Bury culled potatoes; do not throw them on the compost pile.
Solution 2: Buy certified seed potatoes to reduce the risk of introducing late blight.

Solution 1: Avoid overhead irrigation, and promote good airflow within the canopy
Solution 2: Open vents on greenhouses or roll-up sidewalls on high tunnels to keep humidity levels below the favorable range

Solution 1: Prune and destroy infected leaves and plant debris to reduce the spread of Septoria leaf spot.
Solution 2: Use fungicides like chlorothalonil or copper-based products to prevent and manage Septoria leaf spot.

Disease: Spider Mites or Two-Spotted Spider Mite
Solution 1: Use miticides or insecticidal soap to control spider mites on tomato plants
Solution 2: Increase humidity and ensure adequate watering to create an unfavorable environment for spider mites.

Solution 1: Use fungicides containing pyraclostrobin or fluopyram to control target spot on tomato plants.
Solution 2: Rotate crops to prevent the buildup of target spot pathogens in the soil.

Solution 1: Remove and destroy infected plants to prevent the virus from spreading to healthy tomatoes.
Solution 2: Plant virus-free seeds and consider using resistant tomato varieties to prevent infection.

Solution 1: Apply insecticides to control whiteflies, which are the vectors of the tomato yellow leaf curl virus.
Solution 2: Remove infected tomato plants and weeds that could harbor the virus and whiteflies
